Package vendingMachine

Class VendingMachine

  • java.lang.Object
    • vendingMachine.VendingMachine

  • public class VendingMachine
extends java.lang.Object

    VendingMachine

    This is a sample project that implements a vending machine-- a common coding exercise from the web.

    The machine is implemented by this class and tested with VendingMachineTest. JUnit rates the code coverage about 93%.

    The model is one of those glass fronted machines with a different item in each row, selected by a label tag. The machine processes coins correctly and can be reloaded.

    UI: You can enter a kind of money, such as "quarter", or the label of an item to vend, or "refund", "restock', or "quit".

    The data for the restock list is generated by retrieveRestockData(). It is currently hard-wired, but it could be made to get data from a file or database. When making change during vending, the optimal combination of coins is returned, favoring larger coins over smaller.

    Since:
    2018-08=26
    Version:
    1.1
    Author:
    Paul Dworkin

        This is up-top for accessibility.

        Parameters:
        number - Takes an optional int which specifies the number of each coin. Otherwise a default number is used.
        Returns:
        Map telling how many of each kind of Coin to use

      • makeChange

        boolean makeChange​(double amount)
        Generates a configuration of change that satisfies a amount. Returns false if it can't find any. If successful, the amounts of each type of coin are deducted from the machine on the recursion's way back up.

        The chosen result in optimal in that it will choose more of a large coin in preference to smaller ones. That gives the machine more flexibility in making change in the future.

        Parameters:
        amount - Amount of change to make
        Returns:
        True if a combination of change was found

      • listGoods

        java.util.List<VendingMachine.ItemRow> listGoods​()
        An output method that displays what's for sale in the machine. 0 or more labeled rows, the items they contain and their prices.
        Returns:
        The contents of the machine for testing purposes

      • restockMachine

        java.util.List<VendingMachine.ItemRow> restockMachine​(java.util.List<VendingMachine.ItemRow> goods,
                                                      java.util.Map<VendingMachine.Coin,java.lang.Integer> money)
        Takes a List of new goods and adds them to the machine's contents, also takes a Map to reset the quantity of each kind of Coin. Remember: the goods ADD, the money REPLACES. I assume this is the desired behavior for servicing a vending machine.

        There are two methods that typically generate the data to pass to this method. They are retrieveRestockGoods() and retrieveRestockMoney().

        Parameters:
        goods - The ItemRows to add to the machine. If there are tags that duplicate what's already in the machine, the ItemRow's quantity will either be added to it or rejected depending on whether the Items they contain are equal). If null, no action will be taken on the machine contents.
        money - Maps Coins to the quantity that there should be in the machined. If null, no action will be taken on the machine's money.
        Returns:
        The updated contents of the machine. For testing purposes.

      • doCoin

        double doCoin​(VendingMachine.Coin coin)
        Process one coin inserted into the machine.
        Parameters:
        coin - The coin to add
        Returns:
        The total now in the machine. For testing purposes.

      • doRefund

        double doRefund​()
        Refunds all Coins in the purchase buffer. Clears the purchase buffer.
        Returns:
        The total refunded. For testing purposes.

      • doLabel

        java.lang.Object doLabel​(java.lang.String label)
        Finds what Item the given label points to and if the user can afford it, and we can make change for it, vend the item and return change. Any other condition generates the appropriate advisory message.
        Parameters:
        label - The label of the Item we wish to purchase
        Returns:
        For testing purposes: if successfully vending, the item vended; if the price is too high, the extra amount needed; otherwise null.

      • start

        void start​()
        Main loop for exercising functionality in class VendingMachine. Displays machine state and then prompts for an command. Repeats until it receives "quit".

      • main

        public static void main​(java.lang.String... args)
